The following theorem is valid in Euclidean geometry:

If two lines ($\ell$ and $m$) are cut by a third line, called a
*transversal* ($t$), and one pair of corresponding angles ( $\alpha$ and
$\beta$) are congruent, then the cut lines are parallel.

Its converse theorem is also valid in Euclidean geometry:

If two parallel lines ($\ell$ and $m$) are cut by a transversal ($t$),
then each pair of corresponding angles (e.g. $\alpha$ and $\beta$) are
congruent.

The angle $\beta$ in both theorems may be replaced with its *vertical
angle* $\beta_1$. The angles $\alpha$ and $\beta_1$ are called
*alternate interior angles* of each other.

Two lines that are perpendicular to the same line are parallel to each
other.

If a line is perpendicular to one of two parallel lines, then it is also
perpendicular to the other.

If the left sides of two convex angles are parallel (or alternatively
perpendicular) as well as their right sides, then the angles are
congruent.
